sense.name: select carefully from a group
sense.commentary: NOTE: be careful not to include the VPC PICK_OUT in this sense (even though it has a similar meaning)--for all VPCs, choose the last sense
sense.examples: She finally picked her successor. Sports Illustrated ruffled feathers when they picked the Panthers to win the Super Bowl. Hovind insisted that he pick the judges himself without any confirmation of their neutrality. Looks like I picked the wrong week to quit sniffing glue.

sense.name: look for and gather/pluck
sense.examples: Shuksan and Rainier strawberries are picked fresh daily and are of commercial quality. If you picked the flowers from the parking lot at work you lose points. I picked the vegetables from the vine myself and brought them to you!

sense.name: lightly pluck or hit at
sense.commentary: Note: can be used metaphorically Includes: PICK ON
sense.examples: After slow-cooking, you can easily pick the meat off the bone. Remove the leg quarters from the pan and pick the bones clean. Presley's Vince Everett learns how to pick a guitar while doing time in Jailhouse Rock. She just picked her sandwich, but never really ate anything. Quit picking on me! I've got a bone to pick with you.

sense.name: steal
sense.commentary: Note: used in the idiomatic expression "pick pockets"
sense.examples: How now, Dame Partlet, have you inquired yet who picked my pocket?

sense.name: strike hard
sense.examples: The next day we chopped and picked the ice out and built fires inside. The skater picked the ice with her skate.

sense.name: trigger, incite (an argument)
sense.examples: If you're gonna pick a fight with a technology cult, for Pete's sake, don't go after the Linux nerds.

sense.name: physically lift
sense.commentary: Includes: PICK UP NOTE: This sense is reserved only for the physical act of lifting.
sense.examples: If she starts to cry, pick her up and give her a cuddle. I went to pick up the receiver, but it had stopped ringing. He picked the book up from the table and held it in his hands.

sense.name: get, acquire, gather, or collect
sense.examples: He picked up the book and started to read. Have you ever picked up a hitchhiker? She picked up the children at the day care center. Where should he go in the waning hours of the campaign to pick up more votes? I picked up some food for snack. I really picked up a bargain during the weekend sale.

sense.name: notice or perceive; learn without being taught
sense.examples: In most cases people are able to pick up the signal within a day. I was always the one that picked up the smell of the flats first. Police dogs picked up the scent of the two men from clothes they had left behind. She is quick on picking up on the seasonal trends. Someone is bound to pick up you are new to this job. When you live in a country you soon pick up the language.

sense.name: increase or improve
sense.examples: The wind picked up late Saturday afternoon. I'm hoping that the number will pick up as soon as this season is over. I watched it at a very low time in my life and it picked up my spirits. Her performance in school really picked up. Her acting career picked up as she started appearing in sitcoms.

sense.name: emphasize
sense.examples: The lettering was later picked out in gold lustre. The scarf picks up the color of the skirt.

sense.name: recognize, choose, and take from a selection
sense.examples: It is easy for them to pick off the most lucrative business and ignore the rest. I scan through daily and pick off the best articles. At the shop, Jen picked out a red tea named chocolate mint over ice. Can you pick out the three deliberate mistakes in this paragraph? The critics picked him out as the outstanding male dancer of the decade. They hang around until the fish are thoroughly picked over in February.

sense.name: criticize; find fault with
sense.examples: My master picked his defenses apart with ruthless efficiency. You fail to see the main points and want to pick apart the argument devoid of context. He picked at the way in which the papers were not referenced correctly.

sense.name: lightly pluck or hit at
sense.examples: He shook his head and picked at the dust between his feet. Stop picking at your face and make it bleed. Often he sat alone and just picked at his food.

sense.name: arrest
sense.examples: He was picked up by the police for drug dealing. The police picked her up just outside Canterbury.

sense.name: make sexual or romantic advances
sense.examples: In the '70s, you picked up women by blowing cigarette smoke in their face. A man works odd jobs, picks up women, and drinks.

sense.name: shoot or target one by one
sense.examples: I fired, raising a sweat as I picked the targets off again without a miss. Most of the chickens that roosted outside soon got picked off by various predators.

sense.name: accept a challenge
sense.examples: He is bound to pick up the gauntlet thrown down by McClaren.
